Description: Pyramidal stamp-seal of calcite. Octagonal cone, tapered, rounded and pierced near top for suspension on string. Straight cut base that is elongated octagonal in form with bevelled edges and roughly incised design. Design of a quadruped mammal facing right over a pair of disembodied legs.
Curator's comments: Due to its rather slim proportion, this pyramidal stamp-seal seems to be closer to Babylonian types than Persian type (Boardman 1970, 19). A 7th century BC date would fit better. Boardman, J. 1970, ‘Pyramidal Stamp Seals in the Persian Empire’, Iran VIII, 19–45.

Horse or other quadruped mammal over human legs. Head resembles that of a horse, though the tail is unusual. Seal-stone of "Syrian Type". See also examples from Tanis and Defenneh BM, EA 18485, EA 18469, Boston MFA 87.710, 87.711. Assyrian and Babylonian parallels also possible. See for example Late Babylonian seal of similar shape BM 135928.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XX, no. 19)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (PA.04)
